titleInfo.title: Staff Members of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society

physicalDescription.extent: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
physicalDescription.note: Handwritten on envelope: ''#369 Clarence Darrow at JCRS''. On back of photograph: ''#369 L to R Dr. Isadore Bronfin. Staff members of Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society with Judge Ben Lindsey of Denver Juvenile Court and Clarence Darrow 1926 L to R: Dr. Isadore Bronfin, Judge Ben Lindsey, Dr. Leo Tepley, Clarence Darrow, Dr. Charles Spivak, Courtesy Ira M. Beck Memorial Archives Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society Center for Judaic Studies University of Denver.''

mods.abstract: Left to right: Dr. Isidor Bronfin, JCRS medical superintendent and tuberculosis specialist; Denver Judge Ben Lindsey of the juvenile court; Dr. Leo Tepley, JCRS physician; Clarence Darrow, Scopes trial lawyer; and Dr. Charles Spivak, physician and founder of the JCRS. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
mods.note: Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 86.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).
